title: 106_hr605
content: The "Court of Appeals for Veterans Claims Act of 1999" allows the Court to prescribe rules and regulations under Section 7254 of title 38, United States Code. Additionally, the Act includes provisions for the recall of retired judges. The "Court of Appeals for Veterans Claims Act of 1999" allows the recall of retired judges for further service on the Court in accordance with specific requirements outlined in the Act. The "Court of Appeals for Veterans Claims Act of 1999" allows the recall of retired judges who have provided notice of their availability for further service on the Court. The chief judge may recall a retired judge for a period not exceeding 90 days upon certification that substantial service is needed. The "Court of Appeals for Veterans Claims Act of 1999" allows the recall of retired judges for up to 90 days upon certification by the chief judge. A retired judge can be recalled for a total of 180 days in a calendar year with their consent. If recalled and declines to serve (except for disability reasons), they may not be recalled again in the same year. A recall-eligible retired judge may be removed from the status of a recall-eligible judge if they decline to perform service, except for disability reasons. If a retired judge becomes permanently disabled and unable to serve, they will also be removed from the recall-eligible status. Retired judges recalled under this section have the powers and duties of a judge. A recall-eligible retired judge may lose their status if they decline service, except for disability reasons. If permanently disabled, they will be removed. Recalled judges have full powers and duties. Pay for recalled judges varies based on retirement type. During recall status, a retired judge under chapter 83 or 84 of title 5 will receive pay at the rate of an active judge, minus their annuity. They are considered reemployed annuitants under the same chapter. This does not affect their right to serve as a reemployed annuitant under title 5. SEC. 4 amends Section 7296(b) of title 38, United States Code, to only credit years of service as a judge of the Court for calculating service. Fractional years below 183 days are disregarded, while 183 days or more are credited as a full year. SEC. 5 addresses judges' retired pay. Section 7296 of title 38, United States Code is amended to adjust retired pay for judges. Recall-eligible retired judges receive pay based on court judge status. Judges who did not provide notice of availability for service in a recalled status receive retired pay at the rate applicable to them. The retired pay for judges under Section 7296 of title 38, United States Code is adjusted based on their status at the time of retirement. Judges who did not give notice of availability for recall receive pay at the rate applicable to them. Cost-of-living adjustments also apply to retired pay. The retired pay of judges under Section 7296 of title 38, United States Code is adjusted based on their status at the time of retirement. Cost-of-living adjustments apply to retired pay, with specific conditions for retired chief judges to prevent exceeding the annual rate of pay for the chief judge of the court. The retired pay of judges under Section 7296 of title 38, United States Code is adjusted based on their status at the time of retirement. Cost-of-living adjustments apply to retired pay, with specific conditions for retired chief judges to prevent exceeding the annual rate of pay for the chief judge of the court. Coordination with military retired pay is also addressed. The retired pay of judges under Section 7296 of title 38, United States Code is adjusted to ensure it does not exceed the annual rate of pay for the chief judge of the court. Coordination with military retired pay is also addressed for judges serving on the court. SEC. 6. LIMITATION ON ACTIVITIES OF RETIRED JUDGES. A new section is added to Chapter 72 of title 38, United States Code, stating that retired judges forfeit their retired pay if they represent clients in claims related to veterans' benefits against the United States or its agencies. SEC. 7. EARLY RETIREMENT AUTHORITY FOR CURRENT JUDGES TO PROVIDE STAGGERED TERMS. Retirement Authorized: One eligible judge may retire each year from 1999 to 2003. Eligible Judges: An associate judge of the US Court of Appeals for Veterans Claims with 10 years of service, retired pay election, 20 years of service, and at least 55 years old. Multiple Eligible Judges: If more than one judge provides notice, the one with the most seniority retires. An eligible judge may retire each year from 1999 to 2003 if they meet certain criteria, including being at least 55 years old and having 10 years of service. If multiple judges qualify, the one with the most seniority retires. Written notice must be provided to the President and chief judge by April 1 of the retirement year. An eligible judge may retire each year from 1999 to 2003 by providing written notice to the President and chief judge by April 1 of the retirement year. The retirement date specified in the notice is irrevocable, and the judge shall be retired during the fiscal year in which the notice is provided, not earlier than 90 days after the notice date. In accordance with this section, a judge retired shall be retired during the fiscal year in which notice is provided, not earlier than 90 days after the notice date. The rate of retired pay for a judge retiring in accordance with this section is determined by specific provisions. The rate of retired pay for a judge retiring under section 7296(b)(1) of title 38, United States Code is calculated based on years of service and age, with adjustments available for judges available for recall. The rate of retired pay for judges retiring under section 7296(b)(1) of title 38, United States Code is calculated based on years of service and age, with adjustments available for recall-eligible retired judges under section 7257 of title 38, United States Code. An adjustment in annuities payable under civil service retirement laws shall apply to retired pay for judges who are recall-eligible or were removed from recall status due to disability. The duty of the actuary under section 7298(e)(2) of title 38, United States Code is amended to include new subparagraphs. The duty of the actuary under section 7298(e)(2) of title 38, United States Code is amended to include a new subparagraph (C) for determining the present value of payments under subsection (b) from the retirement fund.
